column1: Bitmap index design and evaluation,Chee-Yong Chan

column1: Finding k-dominant skylines in high dimensional space,Chee-Yong Chan
column3: Kian-Lee Tan
column4: Anthony KH Tung
column5: Zhenjie Zhang,Abstract Given a d-dimensional data set
column6: a point p dominates another point q if it is betterthan or equal to q in all dimensions and better than q in at least one dimension. A point is askyline point if there does not exists any point that can dominate it. Skyline queries
column7: whichreturn skyline points
column8: are useful in many decision making applications. Unfortunately
column9: as thenumber of dimensions increases
column10: the chance of one point dominating another point is verylow. As such
column11: the number of skyline points become too numerous to offer any interestinginsights. To find more important and meaningful skyline points in high dimensional space
column12: we propose a new concept
column13: called k-dominant skyline which relaxes the idea of dominanceto k-dominance. A point p is said to k-dominate another point q if there are k≤ d dimensionsin which p is better than or equal to q and is better in at least one of these k dimensions. A …,Proceedings of the 2006 ACM SIGMOD international conference on Management of data,2006,433

While region encodingsupports efficient determination of structural relationship between two elements

column6: we propose a newlabeling scheme
column7: called extended Dewey. This is a powerful labeling scheme
column8: since from thelabel of an element alone
column9: we can derive all the elements names along the path from theroot to the element. Based on extended Dewey
column10: we design a novel holistic twig joinalgorithm
column11: called TJFast. Unlike all previous algorithms based on region encoding
column12: toanswer a twig query
column13: TJFast only needs to access the labels of the leaf query nodes …,Proceedings of the 31st international conference on Very large data bases,2005,379

column1: Secure XML querying with security views,Wenfei Fan
column3: Minos Garofalakis,Abstract The prevalent use of XML highlights the need for a generic
column4: flexible access-controlmechanism for XML documents that supports efficient and secure query access
column5: withoutrevealing sensitive information unauthorized users. This paper introduces a novel paradigmfor specifying XML security constraints and investigates the enforcement of such constraintsduring XML query evaluation. Our approach is based on the novel concept of security views
column6: which provide for each user group (a) an XML view consisting of all and only the informationthat the users are authorized to access
column7: and (b) a view DTD that the XML view conforms to.Security views effectively protect sensitive data from access and potential inferences byunauthorized user
column8: and provide authorized users with necessary schema information tofacilitate effective query formulation and optimization. We propose an efficient algorithm …,Proceedings of the 2004 ACM SIGMOD international conference on Management of data,2004,344

column1: On high dimensional skylines,Chee-Yong Chan
column3: Kian-Lee Tan
column4: Anthony KH Tung
column5: Zhenjie Zhang,Abstract In many decision-making applications
column6: the skyline query is frequently used to find aset of dominating data points (called skyline points) in a multi-dimensional dataset. In a high-dimensional space skyline points no longer offer any interesting insights as there are toomany of them. In this paper
column7: we introduce a novel metric
column8: called skyline frequency thatcompares and ranks the interestingness of data points based on how often they are returnedin the skyline when different number of dimensions (ie
column9: subspaces) are considered.Intuitively
column10: a point with a high skyline frequency is more interesting as it can be dominated onfewer combinations of the dimensions. Thus
column11: the problem becomes one of finding top-kfrequent skyline points. But the algorithms thus far proposed for skyline computation typicallydo not scale well with dimensionality. Moreover
column12: frequent skyline computation requires …,International Conference on Extending Database Technology,2006,261

column1: Multiway slca-based keyword search in xml data,Chong Sun
column3: Amit K Goenka,Abstract Keyword search for smallest lowest common ancestors (SLCAs) in XML data hasrecently been proposed as a meaningful way to identify interesting data nodes inXML datawhere their subtrees contain an input set of keywords. In this paper
column4: we generalize thisuseful search paradigm to support keyword search beyond the traditional AND semantics toinclude both AND and OR boolean operators as well. We first analyze properties of the LCAcomputation and propose improved algorithms to solve the traditional keyword searchproblem (with only AND semantics). We then extend our approach to handle generalkeyword search involving combinations of AND and OR boolean operators. Theeffectiveness of our new algorithms is demonstrated with a comprehensive experimentalperformance study.,Proceedings of the 16th international conference on World Wide Web,2007,243

column12: we establish a number of optimality results for the existing encoding …,ACM SIGMOD Record,1999,243

column1: Stratified computation of skylines with partially-ordered domains,Chee-Yong Chan

column8: and SDC(Stratification by Dominance Classification) and SDC+ are optimized to handle falsepositives and support progressive evaluation. column1: How to ConQueR why-not questions,Quoc Trung Tran
column2: Chee-Yong Chan,Abstract One useful feature that is missing from today's database systems is an explaincapability that enables users to seek clarifications on unexpected query results. There aretwo types of unexpected query results that are of interest: the presence of unexpected tuples

column8: theproblem of explaining the why-not questions has received very little attention. There arecurrently two explanation models proposed for why-not questions. The first model explains amissing tuple t in terms of modifications to the database such that t appears in the query …,Proceedings of the 2010 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of data,2010,116

column1: Finch: Evaluating reverse k-nearest-neighbor queries on location data,Wei Wu
column3: Chee-Yong Chan
column4: Kian-Lee Tan,Abstract A Reverse k-Nearest-Neighbor (RkNN) query finds the objects that take the queryobject as one of their k nearest neighbors. We present an algorithm named INCH that can compute a RkNN query'ssearch region (from which the query result candidates are drawn). In our RkNN evaluationalgorithm called FINCH
column5: the search region restricts the search space
column6: and the search regionis tightened each time a new result candidate is found. We also propose a method thatenables us to apply any RkNN algorithm on bichromatic RkNN queries. With that
column7: our FINCHalgorithm is also used to evaluate bichromatic RkNN queries. Experiments show that oursolutions are more efficient than existing algorithms.,Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment,2008,114

column1: Hierarchical cubes for range-sum queries,Chee Yong Chan
column2: Yannis E Ioannidis,Abstract A range-sum query sums over all selected cells of an OLAP data cube where theselection is specified by ranges of contiguous values for each dimension. An efficientapproach to process such queries is to precompute a prefix cube (PC)
column3: which is a cube ofthe same dimensionality and size as the original data cube but with a prefix range-sumstored in each cell. Using a PC
column4: any range-sum query can be evaluated at a cost that isindependent of the size of the sub-cube circumscribed by the query. However
column5: a drawback ofPCs is that they are very costly to maintain. Recently
column6: a variant of prefix cubes calledRelative Prefix Cubes (RPC) has been proposed to alleviate this problem. In this paper
column7: wepropose a new class of cube representations called Hierarchical Cubes
column8: which is based ona design framework defined by two orthogonal dimensions. Our results show that a …,Proceedings of the 25th VLDB Conference,1999,94

column1: DTD-directed publishing with attribute translation grammars,Michael Benedikt

column8: and gives efficient algorithms for evaluating ATGs. There are keydifferences between ATGs and traditional attribute grammars. A traditional AG is definedwith a context free grammar and more complicated attributes (synthesized and inherited). Ittakes a string as an input

column16: forconstructing query automata and for querying text files. These are mild variations oftraditional AGs and are quite different from ATGs.DTD-Directed Publishing with Attribute …,*,2002,77

column1: Continuous reverse k-nearest-neighbor monitoring,Wei Wu

column4: Kian-Lee Tan,The processing of a Continuous Reverse k-Nearest-Neighbor (CRkNN) query on movingobjects can be divided into two sub tasks: continuous filter

Existing CRkNN solutionsemploy Continuous k-Nearest-Neighbor (CkNN) queries for both continuous filter andcontinuous refinement. We analyze the CkNN based solution and point out that when k≫ 1the refinement cost becomes the system bottleneck. We propose a new continuousrefinement method called CRange-k. In CRange-k
column6: we transform the continuous verificationproblem into a Continuous Range-k query

column1: Taming XPath queries by minimizing wildcard steps,Chee-Yong Chan
column3: Yiming Zeng,Abstract This paper presents a novel and complementary technique to optimize an XPathquery by minimizing its wildcard steps. Our approach is based on using a general compositeaxis called the layer axis
column4: to rewrite a sequence of XPath steps (all of which are wildcardsteps except for possibly the last) into a single layer-axis step. We describe an efficientimplementation of the layer axis and present a novel and efficient rewriting algorithm tominimize both non-branching as well as branching wildcard steps in XPath queries. We alsodemonstrate the usefulness of wildcard-step elimination by proposing an optimizedevaluation strategy for wildcard-free XPath queries that enables selective loading of only therelevant input XML data for query evaluation. Our experimental results not only validate thescalability and efficiency of our optimized evaluation strategy
column5: but also demonstrate the …,Proceedings of the Thirtieth international conference on Very large data bases-Volume 30,2004,46

column1: Processing spatial keyword query as a top-k aggregation query,Dongxiang Zhang
column3: Kian-Lee Tan,Abstract We examine the spatial keyword search problem to retrieve objects of interest thatare ranked based on both their spatial proximity to the query location as well as the textualrelevance of the object's keywords. Existing solutions for the problem are based on eitherusing a combination of textual and spatial indexes or using specialized hybrid indexes thatintegrate the indexing of both textual and spatial attribute values. In this paper
column4: we propose anew approach that is based on modeling the problem as a top-k aggregation problem whichenables the design of a scalable and efficient solution that is based on the ubiquitousinverted list index. Our performance study demonstrates that our approach outperforms thestate-of-the-art hybrid methods by a wide margin.,Proceedings of the 37th international ACM SIGIR conference on Research & development in information retrieval,2014,38

column1: PathStack¬: a holistic path join algorithm for path query with not-predicates on XML data,Enhua Jiao
column3: Chee-Yong Chan,Abstract The evaluation of path queries forms the basis of complex XML query processingwhich has attracted a lot of research attention. However
column4: none of these works haveexamined the processing of more complex queries that contain not-predicates. In this paper
column5: we present the first study on evaluating path queries with not-predicates. We propose anefficient holistic path join algorithm
column6: PathStack¬
column7: which has the following advantages:(1) itrequires only one scan of the relevant data to evaluate path queries with not-predicates
column8: (2) itdoes not generate any intermediate results
column9: and (3) its memory space requirement isbounded by the longest path in the input XML document. We also present an improvedvariant of PathStack¬ that further minimizes unnecessary computations.,International Conference on Database Systems for Advanced Applications,2005,36

column1: Efficient processing of skyline queries with partially-ordered domains,C-Y Chan
column3: K-L Tan,Many decision support applications are characterized by several features:(1) the query istypically based on multiple criteria
column4: (2) there is no single optimal answer (or answer set)
column5: (3)because of (2)
column6: users typically look for satisfying answers
column7: (4) for the same query
column8: differentusers
column9: dictated by their personal preferences
column10: may find different answers meeting theirneeds. As such
column11: it is important for the DBMS to present all interesting answers that may fulfilla user's need. In this article
column12: we focus on the set of interesting answers called the skyline.Given a set of points
column13: the skyline comprises the points that are not dominated by other points.A point dominates another point if it is as good or better in all dimensions and better in atleast one dimension. We address the novel and important problem of evaluating skylinequeries involving partially-ordered attribute domains.,Data Engineering

column1: Efficient scheduling of page access in index-based join processing,Chee Yong Chan

column1: An efficient publish/subscribe index for e-commerce databases,Dongxiang Zhang
column3: Kian-Lee Tan,Abstract Many of today's publish/subscribe (pub/sub) systems have been designed to copewith a large volume of subscriptions and high event arrival rate (velocity). However

column5: there is an increasing variety of items
column6: each withdifferent attributes. This leads to a very high-dimensional and sparse database that existingpub/sub systems can no longer support effectively. In this paper

column8: the arrival rate ofevents and the variety of subscribable attributes. The index is also extensible to supportcomplex scenarios such as prefix/suffix filtering and regular expression matching. Weconduct extensive experiments on synthetic datasets and two real datasets (AOL query logand Ebay products). The results demonstrate the superiority of our index over state-of-the …,Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment,2014,29

column8: we propose efficient algorithms to both compute a singleminimal query as well as enumerate all minimal queries. In addition
column9: we also develop …,Proceedings of the 2008 ACM SIGMOD international conference on Management of data,2008,23

column1: Prefix path streaming: A new clustering method for optimal holistic XML twig pattern matching,Ting Chen
column3: Chee-Yong Chan,Abstract Searching for all occurrences of a twig pattern in a XML document is an importantoperation in XML query processing. Recently a class of holistic twig pattern matchingalgorithms has been proposed. Compared with the prior approaches

column1: Zinc: Efficient indexing for skyline computation,Bin Liu

column1: Indexing OODB instances based on access proximity,Chee Yong Chan

column8: and identify optimization opportunities that allow us tooptimize the evaluation of a set of window functions. We have integrated our scheme intoPostgreSQL. Our comprehensive experimental study on the TPC-DS datasets as well as …,Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment,2012,18

column1: Transaction healing: Scaling optimistic concurrency control on multicores,Yingjun Wu

Transaction healingcaptures the dependencies across operations within a transaction prior to its execution.Instead of blindly rejecting a transaction once its validation fails
column9: the proposed mechanismjudiciously restores any non-serializable operation and heals inconsistent transaction …,Proceedings of the 2016 International Conference on Management of Data,2016,12

column1: Sort-sharing-aware query processing,Yu Cao

column11: that enables sort sharing between seemingly non-related sort orders. Subsequently
column12: given a specific set of sort orders

column4: USA
column5: in conjunction with the 17th InternationalConference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM)

column13: and processed to provide usefulknowledge to the end users for various advanced database applications. The call for papersresulted in the submission of 53 papers from 22 countries. column16: and finally Ranking and Similarity Search.,ACM SIGMOD Record,2009,*

column1: Data Quality and High-dimensional Data Analysis: Proceedings of the DASFAA 2008 Workshops,Chee-Yong Chan,Poor data quality is known to compromise the credibility and efficiency of commercial andpublic endeavours. Also

column3: formats and volume of data grows. This volume targets the dataquality in the light of collaborative information systems where data creation and ownership isincreasingly difficult to establish.,*,2009,*

column1: Optimization of Analytic Queries in RDBMS,Yu Cao
column3: Jie Li
column4: Kian-Lee Tan,ABSTRACT Analytic functions represent the state-of-the-art way of performing complex dataanalysis within a single SQL statement. In particular
column5: an important class of analytic functionsthat has been frequently used in commercial systems to support OLAP and decision supportapplications is the class of window functions. A window function returns for each input tuplea value derived from applying a function over a window of neighboring tuples. However
column6: existing window function evaluation approaches are based on a naive sorting scheme. Inthis paper
column7: we study the problem of optimizing the evaluation of window functions. Wepropose several efficient techniques
column8: and identify optimization opportunities that allow us tooptimize the evaluation of a set of window functions. We have integrated our scheme intoPostgreSQL. Our comprehensive experimental study on the TPC-DS datasets as well as …,*,*,*
